name: Istanbul
fun_fact: Fun fact: Istanbul is the only city in the world built on two continents - you can literally have breakfast in Europe and lunch in Asia by crossing the Bosphorus Bridge, a daily commute for millions.

hero_dishes.description: Dozens of small cold and hot dishes including stuffed grape leaves, fried calamari, white cheese, hummus, and eggplant spreads

hero_dishes.name: Istanbul Street Food Mix
hero_dishes.description: Lahmacun (thin crispy flatbread with spiced meat), Pide (Turkish pizza), Simit (sesame bread rings), and Kumpir (loaded baked potato)
hero_dishes.origin_story: Istanbul's street food reflects its position as a crossroads of civilizations - Armenian lahmacun, Anatolian pide, Ottoman simit, and modern kumpir all coexist on the same streets.

signature_drinks.description: Strong black tea served in tulip-shaped glasses, the social glue of Istanbul
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Consumed all day long, especially while sitting at tea gardens overlooking the Bosphorus. Locals add 1-2 sugar cubes and sip slowly while chatting or playing backgammon. Street vendors carry tea in traditional carriers.

signature_drinks.name: Rakƒ±
signature_drinks.description: Anise-flavored spirit that turns milky white when mixed with water, called 'lion's milk'
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: The centerpiece of meyhane dinners, mixed 1:1 or 1:2 with water and ice. Sipped slowly between bites of meze, never drunk quickly. Considered essential for proper meze appreciation.

food_culture_notes: Street food in Istanbul is incredibly cheap - a full meal costs $5-6 USD, making it one of Europe's most affordable food cities
Eating fish sandwiches from boats at Emin√∂n√º is a 100+ year tradition - the theatrical experience is as important as the taste
Meyhane culture emphasizes slow dining - meals with meze and rakƒ± can last 3-4 hours
Simit sellers walk every street carrying bread rings on their heads - the ultimate breakfast on the go
